evidence: a ray passing through the center of a lens will not be deflected
rays parallel to the optical axis will converge to the focal point
parallel rays entering the lens at different angles all meet at a single focal plane
real image forms with a converging lens
virtual image appears to form on the same side as the object
Rule number one says that a ray passing through the center of a lens will not be deflected - it keeps its direction.
triples.o: rays passing through the center of a lens are unaffected by the lens

evidence: Rays passing through the center of a lens are unaffected by the lens.
Rays that are parallel to the optical axis pass before hitting a lens pass through the focal point after the lens and vice versa.
Parallel rays (any angle to optical axis) pass through the same point in the focal plane after refraction and vice versa.

concepts.term: the rays spread apart, and the image appears to form on the same side as the object - that's a virtual image
